text:
one idea inspired by that article: you could use your top-performing articles from GA as the input prompt for GPT-3

so every 30-days or whatever, pull through your top X articles and let AI riff on the structure and content of their titles. you could probably get Screaming Frog involved to also pull through the first Y paragraphs and use that too

what could be _really_ cool is doing different batches based on different dimensions of performance. "here are thirty ideas based on content with the lowest bounce rate," "here are thirty more based on articles with the longest time-on-page"

something like the latter could work really well, because in our <https://www.animalz.co/blog/benchmark-report-2020/|benchmark report> we found that articles with the longest time-on-page were typically tutorials, so it would spit back a whole list of similar tutorial content to create

probably a case where you'd discard 28 and write 2, or else use those 30 ideas as prompts for 1-2 of your own related ideas

if you haven't checked it out <@U017A1PJL04>, we shared a few similar ideas here: <https://www.animalz.co/blog/gpt-3-and-content-marketing/>

text: Does anyone have any resources on the current state of best practices for gated vs. non-gated content? Thanks!

elements.text: Does anyone have any resources on the current state of best practices for gated vs. non-gated content? Thanks!

text: What is the best practice for merging two blog posts? Should you delete the post that is underperforming and update the content on the post that is performing better? Will changing the title affect the SEO for the better performing post? Our blogs are on Hubspot.

elements.text: What is the best practice for merging two blog posts? Should you delete the post that is underperforming and update the content on the post that is performing better? Will changing the title affect the SEO for the better performing post? Our blogs are on Hubspot.

text:
I’d say yes in general to all your questions. Updating high performing content is definitely best practice. But do check why the other content isn’t performing- if it’s poor quality, it could impact your high performing content when merged.

Experimenting is best. If one way doesn’t work, try the other!

elements.text: I’d say yes in general to all your questions. Updating high performing content is definitely best practice. But do check why the other content isn’t performing- if it’s poor quality, it could impact your high performing content when merged.
Experimenting is best. If one way doesn’t work, try the other!

text:
Thanks, <@UJJFDTN8G>. The two posts are on the same topic, but one is better quality.

I'm just nervous about deleting the older post because I don't want to lose any backlinks.

Would it be better to archive the older post and link that to the newer content?

elements.text: Thanks,

. The two posts are on the same topic, but one is better quality.

I'm just nervous about deleting the older post because I don't want to lose any backlinks.

Would it be better to archive the older post and link that to the newer content?

text: Hey Kisha, you should make sure that you have your web team implement a 301 redirect from the old page to the new page, it will pass all SEO value over, and if anyone clicks on links anywhere on your site to the old page, will be brought to the relevant updated version

elements.text: Hey Kisha, you should make sure that you have your web team implement a 301 redirect from the old page to the new page, it will pass all SEO value over, and if anyone clicks on links anywhere on your site to the old page, will be brought to the relevant updated version

text: It's best practice to update any links on your site pointing to that old (301'd) page as well... keeps things moving smooth for Google as they crawl your website, and ensures you consolidate SEO value in 1 URL as best as possible

elements.text: It's best practice to update any links on your site pointing to that old (301'd) page as well... keeps things moving smooth for Google as they crawl your website, and ensures you consolidate SEO value in 1 URL as best as possible

text: Generally, from a content POV, you should ensure you pull any valuable/unique content from the under performing page to use on the better performing page, any images, etc which will add uniqueness and value to users (as well as SEO)

elements.text: Generally, from a content POV, you should ensure you pull any valuable/unique content from the under performing page to use on the better performing page, any images, etc which will add uniqueness and value to users (as well as SEO)

text: use it as an opportunity to take a fresh view of the topic itself and see if you missed anything else as well :thumbsup:

text: Actually I checked the backlinks and they are both small and pretty low quality. I'm just going to try keeping the older post. :blush:

text: :exploding_head:

I guess nothing new to add to what <@U01881ZL1B6> said, but just to second his advice: I would prioritize the top-performing post and then re-direct the older post to that page. Rather than just leave it up and floating, I think it would be a better user experience to direct people to the new, merged post so that they're getting the most relevant, up-to-date, high-quality information.
